description.p: An elven man flashes a grin as several fiends descend upon him. In a quick flurry, the elf harnesses his focus and unleashes a series of powerful blows, bringing down teh fiends to crumple onto the groudn before him.

A human woman stands on the edge of a cliff overlooking a vast forest. Taking a deep breath, she focuses on teh sounds and scents carried by the wind. After a minute, she opens her eyes and gracefully jumps off of the cliff's edge, pursuing her quarry.

A dwarf nimbly evades teh swing of a monster's mighty claws. Upon landing to the side, the dwarf quickly pivots and immediately leaps toward the terrifying beast. HIs glaive at teh ready, the dwarf focuses all of his energy into his swing, delivering a fatal blow as the beast unleashes its final cry.
Hunters and slayers of foul monsters, the mighty yaegers are warriors who studdy the occult and obtain enhanced abilities, senses, and speed with which to better combat the supernatural.

Yaegers are monster hunters, training to refine their bodies, minds, and senses to better fight against foul beasts. They study occultism and the supernatural, and learn the ways of combat to fight against such threats. In addition to their rigorous martial and endurance training, yaegers learn to master their focus and mental composure. Through the use of such focus, they can exercise better control of their resolve and attacks to deliver deadlier blows. When yaegers are on a hunt, they focus almost exclusively on the task at hand.

Once they reach a certain point, a yaeger joins a yaeger guild; a group of yaegers who utilize different abilities to supplement their martial prowess and apporach monster hunting in unique ways. When a yaegar joins a yaegar guild, it involves some type of supernaturally infused induction ceremony; a mystical riutal, a foul concoction, or a special rite. This grants a yaeger supernatural abilities that make them more capable of fighting terribel and otherwordly threats, and often alters their appearance or personality.

By definition, the life of a yaeger is one of adventuring. Until their dying breath, a yaeger dedicates their life to hunting foul creatures and terrifying beasts. From undead and werewolves to aberrations and fiends, yaegers journey to the darkest of realms and the most haunting of places to fight against the vile creatures that threaten the mortal realms.

At their core, yaegers are professional students of the occult and slayers of monsters. This makes them incredibly useful members of an adventuring party, as their skills make them dangerous foes both on and off the battlefield. Since monsters never rest, neither do yaegers, and their work is never done.

In Yvarra, yaegers are the premier and most efficient monster hunters in the world. However, yaegers as they are known in modern Yvarra were not always the monster hunters that they became to be. The origins of yaegers can be traced back thousands of years ago to the now ruined and accursed land of Satama. There, the ancient vyrassa used blood magic to create a group of highly trained 'super hunters' known as reavers. These reavers became an elite order that directly served the Sataman nobility and judicial systems, tracking down criminals and silencing political foes.

When Satama fell alongside Athar and Xelegos during the Age of Calamity, many of the ancient texts and rites surrounding reavers were lost. However, shortly before the rise of the Witch Queens and the Age of Witchcraft, explorers uncovered lost texts detailing the rituals that created reavers. Using what they could translate and uncover, certain groups set about trying to create a new age of reavers in order to combat against the growing threat of monsters and otherworldly entities that began to flood ancient Yvarra. During this time, these new reavers fought against these supernatural forces, and it was not long before academics and arcane scholars began to experiment with the Sataman rituals. Many of these experiments were failures, but the ones that succeeded allowed for the creation of new elite super-hunters to fight monsters. Thus, the yaegers of Yvarra as they are known as now were born.

Nations.Yvarran yaegers can be members of any race, and their guilds can exist in many lands across Yvarra. Some of the most famous yaeger guilds, such as the hexers and pyromants, operate in the Icilian Empire, Kravnia, the Northern Realms, and Soldan.
Races.Yvarran yaegers can be members of any race, though they are most often capran, dwarves, elves, graam, grepkin, humans, isf√∂dda, ursa, and vyrassa.

Yaegers are monster hunters through and through. Very rarely does their role in society at large stray too far from this, though some employ yaegers for various tasks that are best suited for their skills and fighting and tracking.

Though many yaegers specialize in fighting particular types of supernatural entities and beings, a yaeger can wield their ritualistically imbued gifts to combat against any form of extraplanar or otherworldly threat. However, some yaegers often end up fighting mortals as well, frequently becoming involved in political affairs, warfare, criminal activity, and the squabbles of nobles. Regardless of their nature of their work, yaegers primarily pursue supernatural threats and dispose of dangerous magical creatures, often charging for their services or expecting favors for their guilds in return.

The following roles are optional, flavor-driven choices a player can make that can influence what kind of hunter and tracker an Yvarran yaeger can be. You can choose to roll randomly on the table below, choose an option, or work with your GM to create a role.

tr.td: A yaeger that seeks new members for their yaeger guild.
A yaeger that works for the highest bidder, using their skills for hire.
A yaeger that seeks balance between the supernatural and the mortal.
A yaeger that feverishly studies teh paranormal and extraplanar.
A yaeger that hunts any who are causing harm, whether beast or man
A yaeger that seeks only glory and reward for their hunting skills.

description.p: The life of a yaeger is one filled with violence, long periods of travel, and harsh conditions. Because of this, think about why your character decided to become a yaeger in the first place. Was it something that was expected of them, or was triggered by a dark event?

Second, yaegers train with others under the tutelage and instruction of a seasoned yaeger, known as a master. What was your instructor like? Were they careful to teach you all that you need to know, or were they distant and tough on you to learn things by experience?
When making your yaeger character more unique, consider utilizing the following sections and their associated tables: Inception, Master, and Memento.
Not everyone is cut out to be a yaeger; a yaeger's life is filled with turmoil and uncertainty that can drive those who lack dedication and resolve quite mad.
When creating a yaeger, consider what did lead them to take up this life. What was it that motivated them?

tr.td: I come from a long line of yaegers, and my family has stood against the forces of other worlds and the supernatural for generations.
My homeland is being terrorized by supernatural threats, and someone has to put a stop to it. That someone will be me.
I live for the thrill of the hunt, the uncertainty of combat, and thrive off of danger. Thus, the life of a yaeger appealed to me.

I had studied the supernatural and occult before. Knowing the importance of distinguishing dangerous supernatural forces from harmless ones, I became a yaeger to fight against true terrors and protect innocent supernatural beings.
I had a life that was changed forever when my home suffered a tragedy at the hands of a dangerous supernatural force.
I was a prisoner, one sentenced to death until a seasoned yaeger offered me a chance at a new life. Since then, I view the life of a yaeger as my redemption and salvation.

description.p: Yaegers who live to become masters are those with enough experience, wisdom, and resolve to have avoided death at the hands of the supernatural. These masters have grown old in a profession where many die young, sharing their knowledge with new yaegers.
Think about the kind of master you trained under. Who were they? What was your relationship to them?

tr.td: Your mentor was an older member of your family, one who has trained others in your family for years.
You trained underneath a legendary yaeger, one whose accomplishments have become told in stories and songs time and time again.
You were taught by a being of supernatural origin - a werewolf, a fiend, or even a revenant. They taught you to fight and to see things objectively.
Your master was a seasoned yaeger who had seen wars and battles that you had only heard about. This made them tough and stern, and training underneath them was a grueling ordeal.
A yaeger managed to save you from a terrible threat at a younge age. THey grew to see your potential, and decided to train you in the ways of the yaeger.
Your trainer was an unorthodox yaeger, one who walked a fine line between justice and vengance. Training under them was difficult, but you still retain everything they taught you.

description.p: Yaegers carry with them something that represents their story, earned in training or something they pried off of the corpse of a monster they killed.
Consider what kind of memento your yaeger carries. What is it, and how did you acquire it?

tr.td: I wear a necklace that has a tooth from a mighty beast that I defeated on it.
My master passed down to me a book detailing supernatural creatures and occult practices that they had personally encountered.
I carry a trinket from my past life prior to me becoming a yaeger, one from a time before that life was taken away from me and reminds me of what I lost as well as where I am headed.
I still carry the first weapon I ever used to fight with against a terrible creature
I carry with me a trinket that was gifted to me from a being I was meant to hunt but instead saved and helped to get away and start a new life.

description.p: When creating a yaeger, think about what drove your character to take up this life. Did a tragic event occur in their past, or were their lives changed by a monster?
Next, think about how your yaeger perceives and views the occult and supernatural. Do they view all monsters as just that - monsters?
Do they believe many creatures labeled as monsters to be misunderstood, having their own personalities and problems that mortals might not understand or even be aware of?

Additionally, consider your character's personal history with the supernatural prior to the start of the campaign. What occult or supernatural entities have they encountered, and in what way? Were they ignorant to many elements of the supernatural prior to becoming a yaeger? Or have they experienced the paranormal first hand, either willingly or by way of some gruesome and horrifying event that left them scarred?

Finally, discuss with your GM how yaegers are perceived by most people, as well as how common yaegers are in your setting. Are yaegers heralded as saviors? Or are yaegers seen as monsters themselves? Are there famous and established guilds of yaegers, or are yaegers created in secrecy and are no longer as common throughout the world as they once were? Are there any yaeger guilds that are famed for their exploits, having fought off threat after threat? Or are many yaeger guilds dangerous organizations, universally feared for their ritualistic practices and supernatural powers?
Talk to your GM about the role played by yaegers in the campaign.

You can make a yaeger quickly by following these suggestions. First, put your highest ability score in Strength, followed by Constitution or Wisdom. Second, choose a background found in Chapter 4 of this book.
As a yaeger, you gain the following class features.

ul.li: Hit Dice: 1d10 per yaeger level
Hit Points at 1st Level: 10 + your Constitution modifier
Hit Points at Higher Levels: 1d10 (or 6) + your Constitution modifier per yaeger level after 1st
Armor: Light armor, medium armor, shields
Weapons: Simple weapons, martial weapons
Tools: None
Saving Throws: Strength, Wisdom
Skills: Choose three skills from Acrobatics, Arcana, Athletics, Insight, Intimidation, Perception, Religion, and Survival

description.p: You start with the following equipment, in addition to the equipment granted by your background:

ul.li: two martial weapons
a light crossbow and 20 bolts

description.p: Starting at 1st level, you know the best way to hunt your chosen quarry. You gain the following benefits:

ul.li: When you make an ability check made to track a creature you've seen, you are considered proficient in the Survival skill for this roll. If you're already proficient, you add twice your proficiency bonus to the check, provided you're actively tracking the creature.

When you make an ability check to recall lore surrounding a creature you've studied (such as in a library or under another hunter) for at least 1 hour, you are considered proficient in the skill required to remember information about it, such as Arcana or Nature, for this roll. If you're already proficient, you add twice your proficiency bonus to the check, provided you're actively tracking the creature.

sheet.description: When you make a Survival check to track a creature you've seen, or an ability check to recall lore surrounding a creature you've studied for at least 1 hour, you are considered proficient in the skill for this roll. If you're already proficient, you add twice your proficiency bonus to the check, provided you're actively tracking the creature.

description.p: You have acquired an otherworldly lexicon. You learn how to speak, read, and write one exotic language of your choice. You gain one additional exotic language at 6th level and again at 14th level.

Finally at 1st level, your yaeger training has granted you the ability to enter into a heightened state of focus when the thrill of the hunt calls to you. When you roll initiative (no action required), or as a bonus action on your turn, you can enter your focus. While focused, you gain the following benefits:

ul.li: Your speed increases by 5 feet.

Melee weapon attacks you make on your turn deal an extra 1d6 damage. A creature can take this damage only once per turn. This damage increases as you gain levels in this class, as shown in the Focus Damage column of the Yaeger table.
During your turns, you have a bonus to your AC equal to your Wisdom modifier.

description.p: Your Focus lasts for 1 minute. It ends early if you are knocked unconscious or if you end your focus as a bonus action. You can't enter your focus if you are surprised or incapacitated.
You can use this feature a number of times as shown in the Focus Uses column of the Yaeger table. You regain all expended uses of this feature when you finish a short or long rest.

description.p: You adopt a particular style of fighting as your specialty. Choose one of the following options. You can‚Äôt take a Fighting Style option more than once, even if you later get to choose again.
While you are wearing armor, you gain a +1 bonus to AC.
When you are wielding a melee weapon in one hand and no other weapons, you gain a +2 bonus to damage rolls with that weapon.

When you roll a 1 or 2 on a damage die for an attack you make with a melee weapon that you are wielding with two hands, you can reroll the die and must use the new roll, even if the new roll is a 1 or a 2. The weapon must have the two-handed or versatile property for you to gain this benefit.
When you move at least 5 feet directly toward a hostile creature and attack it with a melee weapon attack, you gain a +2 bonus to the attack roll.
When you engage in two-weapon fighting, you can add your ability modifier to the damage of the second attack.

Beginning at 2nd level, you can weave your incredible speed into a graceful mix of offense and defense. When you take the Attack action on your turn, you can choose to gain the benefit of the Dodge action until the start of your next turn.

You can use this feature once. The number of times you can use this feature increases as you gain levels in this class: two at 5th level, three at 11th level, and four at 17th level. You regain all expended uses of this feature when you finish a short or long rest.

description.p: Starting at 3rd level, your speed increases by 10 feet.
At 3rd level, you join a guild of yaegers where you gain supernatural power, known as your Yaeger Guild.

The available Yaeger Guilds are Guild of the Hexer, Guild of the Pyromant, Guild of the Reaver, Guild of the Remnant, and Guild of the Wolf, all of which are detailed at the end of the class description. Your Yaeger Guild choice grants you features at 3rd level and again at 6th, 10th, 14th, and 18th level.

When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can‚Äôt increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
Beginning at 5th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.

When you are subjected to an effect that allows you to make a Dexterity saving throw to take only half damage, you instead take no damage if you succeed on the saving throw, and only half damage if you fail.

ul.li: Being invisible or heavily obscured from you grants no benefit against your attempts to find or detect an object or creature.
You have advantage on Wisdom and Intelligence checks made to track or locate a target.

You roll 2 Focus Dice, instead of one, when you hit with a melee weapon attack. A creature can still only take this damage once on each of your turns.

description.p: The Yaeger Guild of Hexers is composed of yaegers who build upon their knowledge of the occult and supernatural in order to obtain occult power themselves. They learn how to wield magic which they use to supplement their martial prowess and agility.

Induction into this guild often involves obscure ancient rituals that endow them with magical power and superhuman awareness of the mystical arts. In Yvarra, hexers are often seen primarily hunting practitioners of foul magic and those who abuse occult powers.

sheet.description: The Guild of Hexer is composed of yaegers who build upon their knowledge of the occult and supernatural in order to obtain occult power themselves.

description.p: Beginning at 3rd level when you join this guild, your knowledge of the occult and supernatural has expanded even beyond that of other yaegers. You gain proficiency in the Arcana and Religion skills. If you already have one or both of these proficiencies, you instead become proficient in the same number of skills from the yaeger skill list.
Additionally, you learn how to speak, read, and write two exotic languages of your choice.

sheet.description: You gain proficiency in the Arcana and Religion skills. Additionally, you learn how to speak, read, and write two exotic languages of your choice.

description.p: When you reach 3rd level, you supplement your martial prowess with the ability to cast spells.
Cantrips. You learn two cantrips of your choice from the witch spell list. You learn an additional witch cantrip of your choice at 10th level.

Spell Slots. The Hexer Spellcasting table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your witch spells of 1st level and higher. To cast one of these spells, you must expend a slot of the spell‚Äôs level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest.
For example, if you know the 1st-level spell shield and have a 1st-level and a 2nd-level spell slot available, you can cast shield using either slot.
Spells Known of 1st-Level and Higher. You know three 1st-level witch spells of your choice, two of which you must choose from the abjuration and enchantment spells on the witch spell list.

The Spells Known column of the Eldritch Knight Spellcasting table shows when you learn more witch spells of 1st level or higher. Each of these spells must be an abjuration or enchantment spell of your choice, and must be of a level for which you have spell slots. For instance, when you reach 7th level in this class, you can learn one new spell of 1st or 2nd level.
The spells you learn at 8th, 14th, and 20th level can come from any school of magic.

Whenever you gain a level in this class, you can replace one of the witch spells you know with another spell of your choice from the witch spell list. The new spell must be of a level for which you have spell slots, and it must be an abjuration or enchantment spell, unless you‚Äôre replacing the spell you gained at 3rd, 8th, 14th, or 20th level from any school of magic.

Spellcasting Ability. Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for your witch spells, since you are wise to occult magic. You use your Wisdom whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Wisdom modifier when setting the saving throw DC for a witch spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.

center.p: Spell save DC = 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Wisdom modifier
Spell attack modifier = your proficiency bonus + your Wisdiom modifier

sheet.description: You augment your martial prowess with the ability to cast spells.

description.p: By 6th level, you can focus your magic through your weaponry. While focused, you gain the following benefits:

ul.li: You can use a weapon you are holding as a spellcasting focus for your witch spells.
While you are concentrating on a spell, the number of dice you roll for your Focus Damage increases by one.
Your weapon attacks count as magical for the purpose of overcoming resistance and immunity to nonmagical attacks and damage.

sheet.description: While focused, you can use a weapon you are holding as a spellcasting focus, your weapon attacks count as magical, and the number of Focus Dice you roll increases by one, so long as you are concentrating on a spell.

description.p: By 10th level, you gain a bonus to any saving throw you make to maintain concentration on a spell. The bonus equals your Wisdom modifier.

sheet.description: You gain a +{{yaeger:esoteric}} bonus to any saving throw you make to maintain concentration on a spell.

description.p: At 14th level, you can exact revenge upon spellcasters. When you succeed on a saving throw against a spell, you can use your reaction to move up to your speed toward the caster. You can then make one weapon attack against it, provided it is within the weapon's range or reach.

sheet.description: When you succeed on a saving throw against a spell, you can use your reaction to move up to your speed toward the caster and make one weapon attack against it, provided it is within the weapon's range or reach.

description.p: By 18th level, you have become so attuned to magic that you can sense when it has been used. You are aware of the presence of any creature within 100 feet of you that has cast a spell within the past 24 hours. You know such a creature's direction, but not distance, from you. In addition, you can gain the benefits of your Erudite Tracker feature against it.

Additionally, you can break even the strongest of spellcasters. Once per turn when you deal damage to a creature that is concentrating on a spell, the creature has disadvantage on its check to maintain concentration on the spell.

You know such a creature's direction, but not distance, from you. You can gain the benefits of your Erudite Tracker feature against it. Additionally, once per turn when you deal damage to a creature that is concentrating on a spell, the creature has disadvantage on its check to maintain concentration on the spell.

description.p: The guild of yaegers known as the Guild of the Pyromant is the most famous yaeger guild in Yvarra. These yaegers master wielding both blade and flame, unleashing a fury of fire and steel. Induction into this guild often requires rites of fire and burning, such as pyres, hot coals, or branding.

Known as pyromants, these yaegers come from many areas of Yvarra. In the Icilian Empire, these yaegers believe that their fire is divine and a gift from Avessia. In the northern lands of Ulvrand and Vanhamaa, these yaegers bring flame to combat the titans of frost. Some even come from Lonespire, where spireborn call upon glorious dragon fire. Elsewhere, pyromants may claim to wield the fires from the god Hothian, flames of destruction from the god Dayoth, cleansing fires from the Great Beasts, or fires of chaos from the god Quaine.
However they view their fire, all pyromants know that the flames within them must not fade, and that they must keep their will burning to rise from the ashes.

sheet.description: The Guild of the Pyromant wields both blade and flame, unleashing a fury of fire and steel.

description.p: At 3rd level, you can wreathe your weaponry in fire. When you enter your focus, or as a bonus action on your turn, you can cause any weapon you are holding to erupt in flames for 1 minute. These flames do not harm you. When you deal damage to a creature with one of these ignited weapons, you can choose for your Focus Damage to deal fire damage instead.

sheet.description: When you enter your focus, or as a bonus action on your turn, you can cause any weapon you are holding to erupt in flames for 1 minute. When you deal damage to a creature with one of these ignited weapons, you can choose for your Focus Damage to deal fire damage instead.

description.p: Also at 3rd level, you learn how to conjure flames. You learn the produce flame cantrip. Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for this spell. You can cast the spell, as well as make an attack with an existing flame or dismiss it, as a bonus action on your turn. If you do so, you can't cast another spell until the end of your turn.

description.p: By 6th level, your focus roars with mighty fire. While focused, you gain the following benefits:

ul.li: When a creature within 5 feet of you hits you with a melee attack, flames lash out at the creature, and the attacker takes fire damage equal to your Focus Damage. A creature can only take this damage once per turn.
You don't have disadvantage on ranged spell attacks while within 5 feet of a hostile creature.

Once per turn when you hit a creature with an attack that deals fire damage, the fire leaps from the target to a different creature of your choice that you can see within 5 feet of it. The second creature takes fire damage equal to your Focus Damage.

sheet.description: While focused, when a creature within 5 feet of you hits you with a melee attack, the attacker takes 1d6 fire damage once per turn. Additionally, you don't have disadvantage on ranged spell attacks while within 5 feet of a hostile creature, and once per turn when you hit a creature with an attack that deals fire damage, a different creature of your choice that you can see within 5 feet of it takes 1d6 fire damage.

While focused, when a creature within 5 feet of you hits you with a melee attack, the attacker takes 1d8 fire damage once per turn. Additionally, you don't have disadvantage on ranged spell attacks while within 5 feet of a hostile creature, and once per turn when you hit a creature with an attack that deals fire damage, a different creature of your choice that you can see within 5 feet of it takes 1d8 fire damage.

While focused, when a creature within 5 feet of you hits you with a melee attack, the attacker takes 1d10 fire damage once per turn. Additionally, you don't have disadvantage on ranged spell attacks while within 5 feet of a hostile creature, and once per turn when you hit a creature with an attack that deals fire damage, a different creature of your choice that you can see within 5 feet of it takes 1d10 fire damage.

While focused, when a creature within 5 feet of you hits you with a melee attack, the attacker takes 1d12 fire damage once per turn. Additionally, you don't have disadvantage on ranged spell attacks while within 5 feet of a hostile creature, and once per turn when you hit a creature with an attack that deals fire damage, a different creature of your choice that you can see within 5 feet of it takes 1d12 fire damage.

description.p: By 10th level, the fire within you protects your very soul and increases the power of the flames you wield. You gain resistance to cold and fire damage, and while focused, fire damage you deal ignores resistance to fire damage.

sheet.description: You gain resistance to cold and fire damage, and while focused, fire damage you deal ignores resistance to fire damage.

description.p: At 14th level, the fire within you refuses to fade. When you are reduced to 0 hit points, a wave of fire erupts from your body. Each creature within 30 feet of you must make a Dexterity saving throw (DC equals 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Wisdom modifier), taking fire damage equal to twice your yaeger level on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. This wave of fire ignites flammable objets in that area that aren't being worn or carried.

Immediately after this wave of fire, you drop to 10 hit points instead and immediately enter your focus, even if you have no remaining uses of it, and you gain temporary hit points equal to your yaeger level.
Once you use this feature, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest.

sheet.description: When you are reduced to 0 hit points, each creature within 30 feet of you must make a Dexterity saving throw (DC {{yaeger:dc}}), taking {{yaeger:ashes}} fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. This wave of fire ignites flammable objets in that area that aren't being worn or carried. Additionally, you drop to 10 hit points instead and immediately enter your focus, even if you have no remaining uses of it, and you gain {{level:yaeger}} temporary hit points.

description.p: By 18th level, you wield the mightiest of flames. When you deal fire damage using a feature that allows you to use Focus Damage, the number of dice you roll for your Focus Damage increases by one.

sheet.description: When you deal fire damage using a feature that allows you to use Focus Damage, the number of dice you roll for your Focus Damage increases by one.

description.p: Yaegers who belong to the Guild of Reavers are hunters who live for the thrill of battle, often hunting in groups and tearing into their enemies with frenzy and destruction. These yaegers study anatomy and even grow more powerful the closer they step to death's door.

Originally established in the now ruined and cursed lands of Satama, the rites of reaver guild oftens involve combat, sacrifice, and blood. Ancient stories of reavers are often told to frighten children, and it is said that many vyrassa feel a strange calling to the powers possessed by this guild.

In modern Yvarra, reavers are often seen as a dangerous group given their vicious ferocity. Despite this, reavers can sometimes be found in the ranks of armies in Kravnia and Osira. Many reavers also are deeply religious, worshipping gods such as Avessia, Saivon, Serivic Kane, or Dayoth.

sheet.description: The Guild of Reaver are hunters who live for the thrill of battle, tearing into their enemies with frenzy and destruction.

description.p: Beginning at 3rd level, you become stronger the closer you approach death. While you are below your hit point maximum, you gain a bonus to damage rolls equal to your Constitution modifier. If you are below half your hit point maximum, this bonus is doubled.

sheet.description: While you are below your hit point maximum, you gain a bonus +{{constitution:modifier}} to damage rolls. If you are below half your hit point maximum, this bonus is doubled.

description.p: Also at 3rd level, your induction into this guild has granted you insight into anatomy and enhanced your own vitality. You gain proficiency in the Medicine skill, your hit point maximum increases by 3, and it increases by 1 every time you gain a level in this class.

sheet.description: You gain proficiency in the Medicine skill.

description.p: Starting at 6th level, you feel invigorated when in the heat of battle. While focused, you gain the following benefits:

ul.li: Once per turn when you reduce a hostile creature to 0 hit points with a melee weapon attack, you gain advantage on the next melee weapon attack you make.
You treat any result of 1 or 2 on your Focus Damage die as a 3.
Your weapon attacks score a critical hit on a roll of 19 or 20.

sheet.description: While focused, you treat any result of 1 or 2 on your Focus Damage die as a 3, and your weapon attacks score a critical hit on a roll of 19 or 20. Additionally, once per turn when you reduce a hostile creature to 0 hit points with a melee weapon attack, you gain advantage on the next melee weapon attack you make.

description.p: By the time you reach 10th level, you can't be frightened.

sheet.description: You are immune to being frightened.

description.p: Starting at 14th level, your knowledge of anatomy grants you to bring your allies up quickly while in the heat of battle. When you take the Attack action, you can forgo one of your attacks to stabilize a creature you touch. When you do so, the creature gains immunity to all damage until the start of your next turn.

sheet.description: When you take the Attack action, you can forgo one of your attacks to stabilize a creature you touch. When you do so, the creature gains immunity to all damage until the start of your next turn.

description.p: Starting at 18th level, while focused, you can attack three times, instead of twice, when you take the Attack action on your turn.

sheet.description: While focused, you can attack three times, instead of twice, when you take the Attack action on your turn.

description.p: Remnants are yaegers who belong to an ancient guild built upon the arts of necromancy and spiritualism. These yaegers acquire abilities that transform their bodies to adopt the strengths and resiliences of the undead, but at a high cost. Many of these yaegers lose parts of their mortality, personalities, and even some memories of their pasts fade away; effectively becoming a remnant of their former selves.

Those who join this guild often undergo dangerous rites that bring them closer to death, such as ritualistic near death experiences or exposure to obscure necromancy. Many begin to resemble corpses, such as having cold, stiffer skin, dull colored eyes, and veins that appear blackened under the skin.

Remnants in Yvarra originate in far eastern Kravnia, where they battled hostile spirits and undead creatures who pose great threat to the people. While among the most mysterious and esoteric of yaegers, some remnants are said to be members of religious sects who revere the Rotting God, serving as undead protectors and chosen warriors of powerful necromantic energies. Those few practitioners of necromancy in Yvarra often employ remnants to serve and protect them.

sheet.description: The Guild of the Remnant is built upon the arts of necromancy and spiritualism

description.p: At 3rd level, your induction into this guild has drawn you closer to undeath. You are immune to disease, and you do not need to drink, eat, or breathe, but you can ingest food and drink if you wish.
Additionally, when you are reduced to 0 hit points but not killed outright, you can drop to 1 hit point instead. Once you use this feature, you can‚Äôt do so again until you finish a long rest.

sheet.description: You are immune to disease, and you do not need to drink, eat, or breathe, but you can ingest food and drink if you wish. Additionally, when you are reduced to 0 hit points but not killed outright, you can drop to 1 hit point instead.

You are immune to disease, and you do not need to drink, eat, or breathe, but you can ingest food and drink if you wish. Additionally, when you are reduced to 0 hit points, you can drop to 1 hit point instead.

description.p: Also at 3rd level, you can drain the vitality of the living. Once per turn when you reduce a creature to 0 hit points with a melee weapon attack, you regain a number of hit points equal to half the damage dealt. You can't use this feature on constructs or undead.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (a minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a short or long rest.

sheet.description: Once per turn when you reduce a creature to 0 hit points with a melee weapon attack, you heal equal to half the damage dealt. You can't use this feature on constructs or undead.

description.p: By 6th level, you become as unwavering as the walking dead, allowing you to fight on where others would fail and falter. While focused, you gain the following benefits:

ul.li: At the start of each of your turns, you regain hit points equal to your proficiency bonus if you are below half your hit point maximum. You can't gain this benefit if you haven't moved closer to a creature you can see or hear that's hostile to you, or made an attack against such a creature, since the start of your last turn.
Being frightened does not prevent you from moving closer to the source of your fear.
When you use your Mortal Shell feature, you instead drop to a number of hit points equal to your yaeger level.

sheet.description: While focused, being frightened does not prevent you from moving closer to the source of your fear, and when you use your Mortal Shell feature, you instead drop to {{level:yaeger}} hit points. Additionally, at the start of each of your turns, you regain {{proficiency}} hit points if you are below half your hit point maximum. You can't gain this benefit if you haven't moved closer to a creature you can see or hear that's hostile to you, or made an attack against such a creature, since the start of your last turn.

description.p: By 10th level, you become increasingly harder to kill. You can use your Mortal Shell feature even when you are killed outright.
Additionally, when you use your Mortal Shell feature, you immediately enter your focus, even if you have no remaining uses of it.

sheet.description: When you use your Mortal Shell feature, you immediately enter your focus, even if you have no remaining uses of it.

description.p: By 14th level, the strongest of blows mean little to you. When you suffer a critical hit, you can use your reaction to cause it to become a normal hit. Any effects triggered by a critical hit are canceled.

sheet.description: When you suffer a critical hit, you can use your reaction to cause it to become a normal hit. Any effects triggered by a critical hit are canceled.

description.p: At 18th level, you become the embodiment of death. When you enter your focus, each hostile creature within 60 feet of you must make a Wisdom saving throw or be frightened of you for 1 minute (DC equals 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Wisdom modifier). Constructs and undead are immune to this effect. A frightened creature can repeat the saving throw if it ends its turn in a location where it doesn't have line of sight with you, ending the effect on itself on a success.

Additionally, when you take the Attack action on your turn and make an attack against a creature that is frightened of you, you can make one additional attack against the creature as part of the same action. You can deal Focus Damage with this attack, even if the creature has already taken Focus Damage this turn.

sheet.description: When you enter your focus, each hostile creature within 60 feet of you must make a DC {{yaeger:thanatos}} Wisdom saving throw or be frightened of you for 1 minute. Constructs and undead are immune to this effect. A frightened creature can repeat the saving throw if it ends its turn in a location where it doesn't have line of sight with you, ending the effect on itself on a success. Additionally, when you attack a creature that is frightened of you, you can make one additional attack against the creature as part of the same action. You can deal Focus Damage with this attack, even if the creature has already taken Focus Damage this turn.

description.p: The guild of yaegers known as the Guild of the Wolf consists of warriors who not only recognize the strength and cunning of wolves but also seek to emulate such skill and prowess. Induction into this guild generally involves partaking in the blood of wolves, often via strange alchemical mixtures or consuming it, or rituals where inductees wear wolf pelts and dance under full moons or must wear it while partaking in hallucinogenic drugs and concoctions.

Known as wolves, these yaegers are some of the strangest of yaegers in all of Yvarra. Some hail from guilds that revere Great Beasts who assume wolf-like forms, such as Freyune or Ylashra'han. Others simply follow ancient ritualistic practices and sacrificial ceremonies that involve wolves, and some are even members of guilds that have ties to lycanthropy. Fewer still are the yaegers that are mad enough to worship the Mad Hound, Dayoth the God of Madness and Curses. These yaegers often adorn their armor, clothing, jewelry, and weapons with imagery of wolves and moons and fur trimming.

In addition, the rites and rituals used to induct yaegers into this guild often leave the newly initiated with physical alterations, such as sharpened fangs, thicker hair or fur, sharper nails, and a more lithe yet strong frame. Many also possess yellow or dark brown eyes, and have a tendency to sniff the air or the ground when they are tracking a creature.

Whatever their reason for seeking to acquire the strength of wolves themselves, yaegers who belong to this guild are incredible hunters, preferring to fight alongside their comrades to take down their prey.

sheet.description: The Guild of the Wolf consists of warriors who not only recognize the strength and cunning of wolves but also seek to emulate such skill and prowess.

description.p: Beginning at 3rd level, you can communicate with dogs, wolves, and werewolves as if you shared a language.
Additionally, you gain proficiency in the Stealth and Survival skills, if you are not already, and you have advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on hearing or smell.

sheet.description: You can communicate with dogs, wolves, and werewolves as if you shared a language. Additionally, you gain proficiency in the Stealth and Survival skills, and you have advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on hearing or smell.

description.p: Also at 3rd level, you can create a pack that fights, hunts, and moves together. Over the course of a long rest, you can spend 1 hour with one or more willing creatures, up to your Wisdom modifier. A creature that participates in this is considered part of your pack until it uses an action to leave it, you use an action to remove it, or you use this feature again to create another pack. If you die, your pack begins to fall apart; creatures in your pack are aware of your demise, and retain the benefits of your pack for a number of days equal to your proficiency bonus.
While a creature is a member of your pack, it gains the following benefits:

ul.li: Its speed increases by 10 feet.
It can treat a roll of 9 or lower on a Wisdom (Survival) check made to find another member of the pack as a 10.

Once per turn when it deals damage with an attack to a creature that you have damaged within the past minute, the creature deals an additional 1d4 damage of the attack's type. If the attack has more than one damage type, the pack member chooses the damage type.

sheet.description: Over the course of a long rest, you can spend 1 hour with up to {{wisdom:modifier}} willing creatures. A creature that participates in this is considered part of your pack until it uses an action to leave it, you use an action to remove it, or you use this feature again to create another pack. If you die, your pack begins to fall apart; creatures in your pack are aware of your demise, and retain the benefits of your pack for {{proficiency}} days. While a creature is a member of your pack, its speed increases by 10 feet, it can treat a roll of 9 or lower on a Wisdom (Survival) check made to find another member of the pack as a 10, and once per turn when it deals damage with an attack to a creature that you have damaged within the past minute, the creature deals an additional 1d4 damage of the attack's type. If the attack has more than one damage type, the pack member chooses the damage type.

Over the course of a long rest, you can spend 1 hour with up to {{wisdom:modifier}} willing creatures. A creature that participates in this is considered part of your pack until it uses an action to leave it, you use an action to remove it, or you use this feature again to create another pack. If you die, your pack begins to fall apart; creatures in your pack are aware of your demise, and retain the benefits of your pack for {{proficiency}} days. While a creature is a member of your pack, its speed increases by 10 feet, it can treat a roll of 9 or lower on a Wisdom (Survival) check made to find another member of the pack as a 10, and once per turn when it deals damage with an attack to a creature that you have damaged within the past minute, the creature deals an additional 2d4 damage of the attack's type. If the attack has more than one damage type, the pack member chooses the damage type.

description.p: By 6th level, your focus further enhances your wolf-like nature. While focused, you gain the following benefits:

ul.li: When you reduce a creature that is hostile to you to 0 hit points with a melee weapon attack on your turn, you can use your bonus action to move up to half your speed and make a melee attack against a creature within 5 feet of you (no action required).
Moving through difficult terrain costs you no extra movement.
You have advantage on an attack roll against a creature that is hostile to you if at least one of your allies is within 5 feet of the creature and your ally isn't incapacitated.

sheet.description: While focused, moving through difficult terrain costs you no extra movement. and you have advantage on an attack roll against a creature that is hostile to you if at least one of your allies is within 5 feet of the creature and your ally isn't incapacitated. Additionally, when you reduce a creature that is hostile to you to 0 hit points with a melee weapon attack on your turn, you can use your bonus action to move up to half your speed and make a melee attack against a creature within 5 feet of you.

description.p: Starting at 10th level, little hinders you in your pursuit. You can make a running long jump or a running high jump without moving, and your jump height is tripled.
Additionally, when you take the Dash action, your movement increases by an additional 30 feet until the end of your turn.

sheet.description: You can make a running long jump or a running high jump without moving, and your jump height is tripled. Additionally, when you take the Dash action, your movement increases by an additional 30 feet until the end of your turn.

description.p: By 14th level, your pack has become a deadly force to be reckoned with. While a creature is a member of your pack, it has advantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks that rely on moving silently, and it deals 2d4 additional damage instead of 1d4.

sheet.description: While a creature is a member of your pack, it has advantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks that rely on moving silently.

description.p: By 18th level, you can rally your pack to fight together. When you take the Attack action, you can call your pack to attack alongside you as part of the same action. Each member of your pack can move up to half its speed towards the target of your attack and make one attack against the target (no action required). This movement does not provoke attacks of opportunity. Once you have used this feature, you can‚Äôt do so again until you finish a long rest.

sheet.description: When you take the Attack action, you can call your pack to attack. Each member of your pack can move up to half its speed towards the target of your attack and make one attack against the target. This movement does not provoke attacks of opportunity.

description.p: You change a part of your physical appearance. You can alter your appearance in one of the following ways:

ul.li: You change the color and length of your hair.
You change the color of your eyes.
You adjust your height to be up to 3 inches shorter or taller.
You change the shape of your eyebrows, the length of your nose, the size of your ears, or the length of your teeth.
You increase the length of your limbs to be up to 3 inches longer or shorter.
You change the shape of your mouth and lips.

description.p: If you cast this spell multiple times, you can have up to three of its effects active at a time, and you can dismiss any effect as an action.
If you speak in Witchtongue when you cast this spell, you can have up to four of its effects active at a time.

Often used when sealing or making bargains with a witch or crone, this spell allows you to inscribe a personal mark onto an object or creature. The mark can be a symbol, a word, or a brand, and cannot be larger than 3 inches in diameter.

Inscribing the mark does not harm or affect the object or creature that it is inscribed upon, and can take on an appearance of your choosing (such as the mark appearing as if engraved into wood, left as a scar from a brand, stitched into fabric, burned into the surface, or etched as a tattoo).
A target can only be marked by this spell once by you. If you attempt to inscribe an additional mark on the same target, the first mark immediately fades.
The mark lasts indefinitely unless dispelled or dismissed as an action by the caster. The caster perfectly remembers upon what objects and creatures they have inscribed their mark.

If you speak in Witchtongue when you cast this spell, you can cause the mark to appear invisible unless when a trigger condition is met. The triggering condition can be as general or as detailed as you like, though it must be based on visual or audible conditions that occur within 30 feet of the object. For example, you could cause the mark to become visible when a creature says a particular phrase, uses a particular object or the object is used in some way, or during a specific time each day.

A large murder of crows appears in a location you choose within range. The area of the murder consists of up to five 10-foot cubes, which you can arrange as you wish. Each cube must have at least one face adjacent to the face of another cube. Each creature in the area must make a Constitution saving throw. It takes 4d8 thunder damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one, as the crows unleash a wave of dreadful cawing. The crows then vanish. A creature who is deafened is immune to this spell.

If you speak in Witchtongue when you cast this spell, the cawing of the crows is mingled with speech, with some of the crows mimicking the voices of those nearby. A creature who fails its Dexterity saving throw takes additional psychic damage equal to your spellcasting ability modifier.
At Higher Levels:When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, you create one additional cube for each slot level above 3rd.

setters.set: the skull of a crow that has been coated in silver worth at least 25 gp

description.p: Uttering a foul incantation, you attempt to curse a creature that you can see within range. The creature must make a Wisdom saving throw or be cursed for 1 minute. While the target is cursed, multiple shards of arcane energy begin to float around the creature. These shards appear like sharp objects that can take on a form of your choice, but can be no longer than 3 feet each. For example, the shards can take the form of large nails, stakes, short spears, arrows, or needles.

For the duration of the curse, whenever the creature takes the Attack, Cast a Spell, or Use an Object action, the creature takes 1d10 force damage. The creature can repeat their saving throw at the end of their turn, ending the effect on a success.
A remove curse spell ends this curse early.

If you speak in Witchtongue when you cast this spell, whenever the creature takes the Attack, Cast a Spell, or Use an Object action, the creature‚Äôs speed is reduced by 5 feet for the remainder of their turn.
At Higher Levels: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd-level or higher, you deal an additional 1d10 force damage for each slot level above 1st.

setters.set: a coffin nail or a wooden stake burnt at one end

description.p: You touch a willing target within reach, blessing it with a protective ward. For the duration of the spell, the target can't be cursed or possessed, and the target gains a +1 bonus to its AC. Additionally, the target‚Äôs movement speed cannot be reduced for the duration of the spell.

setters.set: a small turtle shell engraved with runic etchings

description.p: You draw wisps of solar power to you as you attempt to curse a creature with fear of the sun. Choose a creature that you can see within range to make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the target is considered cursed and suffers the following penalties:

ul.li: While in sunlight, the target has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on sight.

The creature must also use its movement on its turn to move away from any source of sunlight that it can see. If there is no source of sunlight, the creature instead uses its movement to avoid any source of bright light that it can see, or otherwise takes the Hide action.
When a creature moves into or within an area of sunlight, it takes 2d6 radiant damage for every 5 feet it travels.

description.p: If you speak in Witchtongue when you cast this spell, the target has disadvantage on saving throws against being frightened while in an area of sunlight.
A remove curse spell ends this effect.
At Higher Levels: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 5th level or higher, you can target one additional creature with this spell for each slot level above 4th.

setters.set: the charred skull of a rooster

description.p: Thought to have been first used by ancient hags, this spell sends lightning hurtling towards your foes. You unleash small streaks of lightning and each creature other than you must make a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes 1d6 lightning damage.
If you speak in Witchtongue when you cast this spell, the damage die increases from 1d6 to 1d8.
The spell's damage increases by 1d6 when you reach 5th level (2d6), 11th level (3d6), and 17th level (4d6).

Uttering an incantation, a pale and ghostly form of a skeletal figure composed of moonlight enshrouds your body for the duration, shedding bright light in a 10-foot radius and dim light for an additional 10 feet. You can end the spell early by using an action to dismiss it.

The ghostly form provides you with a shield of radiant lunar energy and blesses you with the calm tranquility of the night, granting you resistance to radiant damage and advantage on saving throws against being frightened.

In addition, whenever a creature within 5 feet of you hits you with a melee attack, the ghostly form retaliates with a spectral strike. The attacker takes 2d8 radiant damage. If the attacker is a shapechanger, it takes an additional 1d8 radiant damage.
If you speak in Witchtongue when you cast this spell, you are instead immune to being frightened.
If you cast this spell outside and with an unobstructed view of the night sky, the spell's damage increases by 1d8.
At Higher Levels: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 5th level or higher level, the damage increases by 1d8 for each slot level above 4th.

setters.set: a skull engraved with carved runes that has been left in the light of a moon for 4 hours

description.p: Your tongue transforms into a long serpent. On each of your turns for the duration, you can use an action to make a melee spell attack against one creature within 10 feet of you. On a hit, the target takes 1d10 poison damage.

You are able to speak and breathe normally while your tongue is transformed in this way. If your serpent tongue is severed for any reason, the part remaining attached to your body reverts back to your normal tongue.
Additionally when you cast this spell, you can speak through the mouth of the serpent.
This spell's damage increases by 1d10 when you reach 5th level (2d10), 11th level (3d10), and 17 level (4d10).

You choose a creature that has a shadow and that you can see within range. The target must make a Strength saving throw. The target has disadvantage on the saving throw if they are not in darkness. On a failed save, the target takes 2d6 necrotic damage as the target‚Äôs shadow emits shadowy tendrils, arms, or chains and is restrained for the spell‚Äôs duration.

To break out, the restrained target can make a Strength check against your spell save DC. On a success, the target escapes and is no longer restrained by their shadow. On a failure, the creature immediately takes 2d6 necrotic damage.

If you speak in Witchtongue when you cast this spell, the a mouth emerges in the target‚Äôs shadow that whispers to the target, and whenever the target would take damage from this spell, the target takes an additional 1d6 psychic damage.
At Higher Levels: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, you can target one additional creature for each slot level above 2nd.
You create two magical serpents made of shadow that immediately lunge at targets within range that you can see. You can cause them to head toward one target or several.

Make a ranged spell attack for each serpent. You have advantage on the spell attack rolls for each serpent if the target of the attack is in dim light or darkness. On a hit, the target takes 1d10 necrotic damage.
When you speak in Witchtongue when you cast this spell, the serpents utter foul curses in Witchtongue before they strike a target, and the spell's damage increases to 1d12 for each serpent.
At Higher Levels: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, you create one additional serpent for each slot level above 1st.

setters.set: a serpent tongue blackened over an open flame

description.p: You choose a portion of a shadow that you can see within range and that fits within a 5-foot cube. You manipulate it in one of the following ways.

ul.li: You cause the shadow of a target creature or object to reshape into a shape of your choice, such as an object‚Äôs shadow or the shadow of another creature. This change lasts for 1 hour.
You cause shapes to appear in the shadow formed out of the shadows themselves, spelling out words, creating images, or shaping patterns. The changes last for 1 hour.
If the shadow you target is on the ground, you cause it to become difficult terrain by forming spikes, hands, or tentacles of shadow to form in the shadow itself. This change lasts for 1 hour.

description.p: If you cast this spell multiple times, you can have no more than two of its effects active at a time, and you can dismiss such an effect as an action.
If you speak in Witchtongue when you cast this spell, you can cause a disembodied voice to speak a repeating word or short phrase to emanate from the shadow in a language that you can speak.

You momentarily conjure a horrifying spirit that lunges toward a creature that you can see within range. The target must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the target takes 1d8 psychic damage and moves 10 feet away from you if it can move and its speed is at least 10 feet. This movement doesn't provoke opportunity attacks, and if the direction is blocked, the target doesn't move. The creature doesn't move into obviously dangerous ground, such as a fire or a pit.
If you speak in Witchtongue when you cast this spell, if the target fails its saving throw, the spirit assumes the form of one of its deepest fears.
The spell's damage increases by one die when you reach 5th level (2d8), 11th level (3d8), and 17th level (4d8).

A large swarm of insects fly out of your mouth. Each creature in a 30-foot cone must make a Dexterity saving throw. A creature takes 4d8 piercing damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
A creature killed by this spell becomes infested by the insects as they gnaw and devour their corpse, if one is left.
If you speak in Witchtongue when you cast this spell, the cone increases by 10 feet.
At Higher Levels: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, the damage increases by 1d8 for each slot level above 2nd.

setters.set: a locust dipped in blackened honey

description.p: You alter your voice to cast deceiving sounds. For the duration of the spell, you can mimic animals sounds and humanoid voices. You can only mimic sounds and voices that you have heard at least once.
A creature that hears the sounds can deduce that they are imitations with a successful Wisdom (Insight) check opposed by your Charisma (Deception) check.

If you speak in Witchtongue when you cast this spell, the sounds and voices you create are almost indiscernible. If you rouse suspicion, or if a doubting creature suspects something is amiss from your sounds or voices, you have advantage on any Charisma (Deception) check you make to avoid detection.

A haunting and ethereal melodic song, composed of unorthodox structure and beauty, fills the air around you in a 30-foot radius. The song spreads around corners and can be heard up to 100 feet away. The music moves with you, centered on you for the duration.

Until the spell ends, the first time a creature enters the area or starts its turn there, the creature must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw. If you or your companions are attacking it, the creature automatically succeeds on the saving throw. On a failure, a creature becomes charmed and becomes friendly to you for as long as it can hear the song, and the charmed target must use its action to move closer to you at half its movement speed. You make Charisma (Deception) checks and Charisma (Persuasion) checks against creatures made friendly by this spell with advantage.
A creature can make a Wisdom saving throw at the end of each of its turns. On a success, the spell ends.
Your speech brings forth wonders of witchery and create one of the following effects within range:

ul.li: You instantly make a flower or small plant begin to bloom or wither. Alternatively, you can cause the flower or small plant to change color or temporarily assume the form of another flower or small plant. This change lasts for 1 minute.

You cause a creature of your choice within range to make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the creature beings to experience harmless effects and symptoms of a bodily and physical disease or medical condition, such as a pox, rot, hives, bleeding, nausea, coughing, sneezing, or swelling. These effects last for up to 4 hours, at which point they fade.

You can create illusory images that appear on a flat and reflective surface (such as a pool of water, a mirror, or a polished table). A willing creature that looks in the reflective surface sees either images of your choice or sees images that reflect their surface orinner thoughts. Such thoughts might be of a loved one or a fear the creature has regarding the future, or something they have done in the past. These images last for 1 minute or until you dismiss them.

You cause a minor supernatural sensation at a point within range. Such an effect can be an illusory image of a specter, a cold snap and shivering goosebumps, the moan of a dying creature, ominous whispers or discordant melodies, or the color of nearby candles to flicker in shifting colors.
You cause nearby non-secured objects to temporarily hover in the air before harmlessly floating back to the ground.

description.p: If you cast this spell multiple times, you can have up to three of its 1-minute or longer effects active at a time, and you can dismiss such an effect as an action.
